title: Sánchez re-elected in tight vote
text:
Socialist leader Pedro Sánchez was re-elected on Tuesday (7 January) as Spanish prime minister by only two votes (167 in favour, 165 against). Together with left-wing party Podemos, he will lead the first coalition government in the country's history since the Second Republic in the 30s.

Sánchez faces a difficult mandate ahead, as the liberals, centre-right and far-right parties offered staunch opposition during the parliament debate forcing him to rely on the Catalan pro-independence party and Basque separatists to pass the vote.

Sánchez said he would prioritise addressing the territorial conflict and fighting against the long-lasting consequences of the economic crisis in the country, still suffering from high levels of debt and unemployment.

But his government will struggle to pass the necessary reforms in education or the labour market, as he would need the centre-right PP to obtain a strong majority.

Even so, the end of the political paralysis in Spain, where four general elections have been held over the past four years, was welcomed by the EU institutions.

European Council President Charles Michel congratulated Sánchez on his reelection.

“This is good news for the EU. Let’s build a greener and fairer Europe together,” he tweeted. A similar message was conveyed by European Commission and European Parliament presidents, Ursula von der Leyen and David Sassoli.

Read also: Allied with far-left, Spain’s Sanchez stays on as PM
